microstructure: single-phase B2 structure; after further annealing at 600˚C, the structure consisted of the bcc and orthorhombic (O-phase) phases
processing_method: vacuum arc melting; annealed at 1200°C for 24 hours; some samples further annealed at 600°C for 24 hours
type_of_test: X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM)
evidence: After annealing at 1200˚C, the alloy had a single-phase B2 structure with the lattice parameter a=0.3304±0.0004 nm. The microstructure consisted of coarse (~400 μm) polygonal-shaped grains with clear boundaries (see a magnified insert in Fig.  3a ); the average chemical composition of the grains corresponded closely to the nominal composition (Fig.  3a , Table  1 ). TEM analysis confirmed the B2 ordering and revealed numerous anti-phase boundaries in the matrix grains (denoted in Fig.  3b  as APBs); no secondary phases were detected. After further annealing at 600˚C, which was found to increase the hardness of the alloy noticeably according to preliminary studies, the structure, however, consisted of the bcc and orthorhombic (Cmcmspace group; hereafter denoted as the O-phase) phases (Fig.  2 ). The lattice parameters of the bcc and O-phases were determined as a=0.3311±0.0003 nm and a=0.6068±0.0002 nm, b=0.9648±0.0003 nm, c=0.4710±0.0003 nm, respectively.

microstructure: single-phase B2 structure with coarse (~400 μm) polygonal-shaped grains with clear boundaries. TEM analysis confirmed the B2 ordering and revealed numerous anti-phase boundaries in the matrix grains
evidence: After annealing at 1200˚C, the alloy demonstrated the yield strength of 830 MPa and high compressive ductility (>50%) at room temperature (Fig.  4a, Table 2 ). Note, the alloy showed pronounced work hardening. At 600°C, the yield strength decreased to 635 MPa, but the alloy retained the same work hardening capacity and high ductility (Fig.  4b ). Annealing at 600C changed the mechanical properties of the alloy noticeably (Fig.  4 , Table  2 ). At 22°C, the yield strength increased by ~50% to 1250 MPa; the ductility reduced but maintained at a moderate level of 16% (Fig.  4a ). At 600°C, the alloy exhibited higher ductility (>50%) and a strength increment (~45%) comparable to room-temperature; as a result, the yield strength raised to 920 MPa (Fig.  4b).

microstructure: B2 matrix after annealing at 1200˚C; Bcc matrix and Widmanstatten (Ti, Al)-rich Ophase particles after further annealing at 600°C
processing_method: Annealing at 1200˚C for 24h, followed by further annealing at 600°C for 24h
evidence: The introduced Ti 40 Nb 30 Hf 15 Al 15 alloy demonstrated some unique for RHEAs features. The alloy after annealing at 1200˚C composed of the single B2 phase that transformed after further annealing at 600°C into a mixture of the bcc matrix and Widmanstatten (Ti, Al)-rich Ophase particles.

microstructure: Bcc matrix and Widmanstatten (Ti, Al)-rich Ophase particles after annealing at 600°C
evidence: Annealing at 600C changed the mechanical properties of the alloy noticeably. At 22°C, the yield strength increased by ~50% to 1250 MPa; the ductility reduced but maintained at a moderate level of 16%.

microstructure: Bcc matrix and Widmanstatten (Ti, Al)-rich Ophase particles after annealing at 600°C
evidence: At 600°C, the alloy exhibited higher ductility (>50%) and a strength increment (~45%) comparable to room-temperature; as a result, the yield strength raised to 920 MPa.
